It transcends the three times, without past, present, or future. It understands all dharmas to be like illusions, transformations, dreams, shadows, echoes, mirages, banana trees, water bubbles, and foam. It understands that the three realms originally do not exist, but arise from conditioned relations. It is beneficial or not, praised or slandered, gains fame or loses praise, and experiences suffering or happiness. It transcends all worldly dharmas. Through skillful means, it circulates through the three evil paths, and transcends the desire realm, form realm, and formless realm. It understands the meaning of the Way and saves all beings.
The devas come to attend and receive the profound Dharma, and their ignorant minds are opened up and enter the illumination of the Way.
At that time, the World-Honored One, in the morning, put on his robe and took his bowl, and entered the city of Vaishali to beg for alms. He arrived at the house of Vimalakirti.

At that time, VimalakÄ«rti had a son named Subodhi. In the morning, he bathed, anointed his body with incense, put on new clothes, held a lotus flower in his hand, and went up to the pavilion with his wife to watch and enjoy the entertainment. It was a response to the roots of goodness from his past lives.

From afar, he saw the Buddha coming with the assembly of sages, entering the city for alms, manifesting great auspicious transformations. He spoke a verse to his wife, singing a eulogy of the Buddha's merits:
Hearing this harmonious sound, all of us are making it together at the same time.
The various musical instruments are in that place, quickly reaching the top of the pavilion;
The Great Hero is coming, there is no doubt. The Protector of the World emits radiance and brilliance,
He will surely use the tip of his right foot to step on the threshold of the city gate.
The birds and various animals let out mournful and harmonious sounds,
Never heard before since ancient times, such wonderful sounds;
The Great Hero is coming, there is no doubt. He wishes to guide and benefit sentient beings,
Now raising the right toe, placing it on the threshold of the gate.
Today I see the Buddha, like a body adorned with jeweled necklaces,
With no music played, yet with subtle and delightful sounds;
The Sage of the trichiliocosm has no doubts, with majestic virtue and pure adornments,
He will surely use the right toe to step on the threshold of the city gate.
It is like a large bowl placed in a pond or river,
Then one hears the sound of harmony, pervading the land;
The god among humans has no doubts, the Great Sage emits the honored light,
The Buddha opens and guides the world, definitely coming to enter the city gate.
With spiritual powers, transforming beings, like a tree with luxuriant flowers,
With various colors and fragrant blossoms, spreading the most beautiful fragrance;
The great dragon has no doubts, vowing to establish the foundation,
Now placing the right toe on the threshold of the city gate.
Universally illuminating the sky, pervading the heavens and earth,
The sun's light is obscured, its radiance never to appear again;
All the honored ones have no doubts, manifesting majestic brilliance,
Now placing the right toe on the threshold of the city gate.
Just like the heavenly beings, dwelling in the sky,
The multitude following the Buddha, like the heavens attending Brahma;
Compassionate towards the world, the honored one, the sagely guide,
Now placing the right toe on the threshold of the city gate.
Today, the people observing the city, each with kindness, harboring no resentment,
Passing on to each other, discussing like parents and children;
Virtuous light, without hesitation, blessings and majestic virtue adorning oneself,
Now placing the right toe on the threshold of the city gate.
Observing the men, women, and children, each holding various flowers,
Joining palms in self-surrender, joyfully scattering flowers from afar;
The great guide without hesitation, the body adorned with the flowers of virtue,
Now with the tip of the right foot, placing it on the threshold of the city gate.
Flowers from the heavens and humans, spread throughout the empty space,
Scattering flowers and burning incense, the fragrance pleasing to the mind;
The greatly courageous one without doubt or entanglement, wishing to enter VaiÅ›ÄlÄ«,
Therefore causing the great assembly to rejoice, the most victorious one has come here.
At that time, the wife of Subhadra, hearing these words, was fearful in her heart, her hair stood on end, and her body felt cool inside. Standing by the side of the grove, she thought to herself:
What kind of spirit is this?
Is it a god, dragon, ghost, ghoul, kumbhÄá¹‡á¸a, mahoraga, human, or non-human?
Speaking human words with its mouth.
In its place, it did not move, did not sway, and did not dare to shift.
At that time, the Buddha went to the village where the youth Sudasaputra lived, and stood in front of the gate by the side of the house.

When the youth Sudasaputra saw the World-Honored Buddha, he wanted to go down from the pavilion to welcome him. He was overjoyed and could not contain himself. He threw himself down from the pavilion, but by the Buddha's holy will, he remained suspended in the air and praised the Buddha in verse:
The Venerable One of Holy Wisdom, please wait. The Hero among Men, have mercy and wait.
For the sake of having compassion for sentient beings, please accept this water and drink.
Then the World-Honored One spoke a verse to Sudasaputra, saying:
Abiding in the true fundamental reality, which is not understood by the worldly.
That reality is non-existent, this is the characteristic of the fundamental reality.
The youth Sudasaputra asked the Buddha in verse:
How does one abide in the fundamental reality?
The transformation and guidance of the true fundamental reality, the stage of reliance on ignorance, what is called establishing emptiness?
At that time, the Buddha again spoke a verse to Sudasaputra, saying:
The true ultimate limit is the limit of the TathÄgata,
Just as one abides in the ultimate limit, one clearly abides thus;
Just as the true ultimate limit is the limit of the TathÄgata,
Just as one clearly understands the true ultimate limit, the youth abides likewise.
The youth SubhÅ«ti again addressed the Buddha in verse, saying:
What is the limit of no limit? What are the characteristics of the limit?
By what skillful means is it called the ultimate limit?
Then the World-Honored One, seeing that SubhÅ«ti's mind wished to understand the path without location, addressed the youth SubhÅ«ti and replied in verse, saying:
The true ultimate limit is said to be without limit and unobtainable,
The characteristics of that limit are like empty space, and empty space also has no characteristics.
SubhÅ«ti spoke a verse to the Buddha, asking:
How profound is the true and proper abode, its abode is profound and unsurpassed,
May all sentient beings abide like the present guide!
At that time, the youth Sudasaputra addressed the Buddha, saying:
The World-Honored One, out of compassion, accepts these lotus flowers.
The Buddha then accepted them.
The youth Sudasaputra spoke with his mouth and body, saying:
By means of this merit, may I attain the unsurpassed, true path and accomplish supreme, perfect enlightenment;
For the sake of all sentient beings, may I expound the scriptures, enabling them not to reach the Dharma of ordinary beings and not to reach the Dharma of the Way.
At that time, the Venerable Shariputra was also in the assembly. He said to the youth Sudasaputra:
What does the mind of Sudasaputra aspire to?
What does the Dharma of perfect enlightenment resemble?
You wish to expound it for the sake of sentient beings.
Sudasaputra answered in verse:
The Buddha's mind attains nothing, and so do the shravakas.
When attaining this perfect enlightenment, expound it for the sake of sentient beings.
They have no direction to speak of, and also nothing to attain,
The greatly wise should understand this, the fundamental purity is like this.
The past rightly enlightened ones, the world-protecting unsurpassed honored ones,
Also did not attain any dharmas, guiding the world due to extinction;
Calculating and seeking the dharma realm, also no realm of sentient beings,
This is then the fundamental limit, not expressed by worldly convention;
Provisionally referred to as the world, people rely on characteristics and names,
Also no various thoughts, no other different activities.
At that time, Binou Wenda Nizi spoke this verse for the youth Shandesi:
Youth, how do you wish to study this dharma?
This place is deeply difficult to attain, the enlightened are confused.
You have been born for a long time, your wisdom is uniquely courageous,
When speaking with the Å›rÄvakas, they suddenly respond with fearless wisdom;
They are able to discern everywhere, their abode is like purple gold,
Standing on the majestic royal road, like the full moon in the sky.
At that time, the youth SudÄna replied in verse, saying:
You ask about what is born, but what is born is unborn;
All dharmas are unarisen, so who will be born again?
Those dharmas are unborn, naturally non-existent,
This is called originally pure, with no dharma and nothing to attain.
All dharmas are originally pure, never able to attain this,
Because of this ignorance and arrogance, the Buddha therefore expounds this Dharma.
Being in the wilderness of the sages, he first turns this wheel,
Preserving the Å›rÄvaka's work, his mind is fixed in emptiness;
Proclaiming the sound of the Dharma, for the many he has eloquence,
Using skillful means to come to the wisdom of the sages, proclaiming and speaking as one would examine and understand;
There is birth and then death, this is the conduct of the foolish,
Dwelling in inverted actions, as spoken by Binnu.
Because of birth there is old age and death, this is a worldly saying,
The Dharma is without words, relying on provisional teachings.
At that time, the Venerable Binnu Wen Tundani spoke to the Buddha, saying:
It is unprecedented, World-Honored One!
Now this youth Sudasaputra has deeply entered into wisdom, lofty and vast, proclaiming what is unsurpassed by the multitude.
The Buddha said:
So it is, so it is!
It is as Binnu says, without any difference.
At that time, the Buddha told the Bodhisattva youth Sudasaputra:
For what reason do you wish to attain the unsurpassed true path and become the foremost perfect enlightenment?
Sudasaputra replied:
The World-Honored One has explained it, so I ask about it again. Because of the greatest sage, I have made great vows. The World-Honored One, the Most Virtuous One, has spoken these words.
My body is tranquil and does not act, but because of making great vows, there are no obstructions. Without anything to transform, this is called the profound and supreme phrase.
Sentient beings are without a self, and so are they. Those who do not rely on this are able to cross over.

The wise one carefully explains the profound and wonderful supreme phrase, understanding the true reality of this basis, with countless variations, penetrating the profound and wonderful supreme phrase, using the Dharma to transform these sentient beings, their practices each different, teaching without sentient beings.

If there are no sentient beings, they are all empty. Without wisdom or ignorance, sentient beings are originally pure. Penetrating original purity, there are no differences. Understanding this meaning is the bright wisdom of the world.
Yes, World-Honored One, I have understood this and have attained perfect enlightenment myself, teaching the Dharma for the sake of sentient beings.
The Venerable Ä€nanda then addressed the Buddha, saying:
It is truly unprecedented that the youth Sudatta's eloquence should penetrate so deeply, that he is able to proclaim these wondrous and appropriate chapters, the phrases of non-attachment.
If the common people of the heavens and the world, and the asuras hear this, they will surely be terrified and unwilling to study it. Who would believe and enjoy this profound and wondrous Dharma?
Only those who have heard and studied this profound practice in past lives will then believe and accept it.
At that time, Ä€nanda praised in verse, saying:
Just as the peak of Mount Sumeru appears far away and wondrous,
So now Sudatta's virtues are like this among the wondrous assembly;
If he is like the king of mountains, firmly abiding in the great ocean,
Now dwelling in this assembly, he joyfully proclaims these wondrous phrases.
What Sudatta praises and extols is said to be neither existent nor non-existent,
Also illuminating the original limit, not observed by worldly people;
His words are fearless, and there is none who does not respect and praise them.
Only the well-intentioned one speaks of it - how does one know the beginning and end?
The well-intentioned one replied in verse:
I have abandoned my body and life, wearing the armor of unobstructedness,
My aspiration is not to crave for perfect enlightenment - that is called extensive learning.
Because of relying on desires one falls, accumulating extreme misfortune.
Who does not fall into calamity? Only seeing the world's guide.
This is the realm of the buddhas, sustained and saved by the guardians of the world,
Their bodies are without distress, abiding in the honored path of the buddhas.
Space and the human body, both are unobtainable,
Just as the Dharma is unobtainable, the Dharma is fearless;
Understanding the Buddha's body in space, truly without location,
If one attains this patience, one will forever be without fear.
Space and earth are naturally non-existent,
This is naturally good thought, penetrating all without location;
Space and earth, good thought cannot be attained,
No arising, no naturalness, empty and tranquil, nothing exists;
Space has no high, it also has no low,
By understanding this Dharma, they are all without fear.
At that time the Buddha told the youth Sudasaputra:
Good man, is your nature without fear?
He said to the Buddha:
No, I do not.ğŸ”½
The World-Honored Buddha asked again:
Are you truly fearless?
He said:
No, I do not.ğŸ”½
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
You are now fearless, without anxiety or fear.
At that time the Buddha spoke a verse:
Fear arises from existence, but what appears is non-existent.
If one can understand this forbearance, then one approaches the Buddha's path.
Because of the thought of a person, there is fear, but sentient beings are originally forever non-existent.
If one can understand this, then there is no dwelling here.
Those who do not attain right enlightenment, non-enlightenment is also like this.
If there is nothing else to gain, then perhaps there is nothing to fear;
If one can understand this, then one does not dwell in the realm of existence or non-existence.
Good thought understands this, and this is due to the Buddha's path.
The Buddha told Good Thought:

If there are bodhisattvas who wish to quickly attain eternal peace and the unsurpassed, true path, and become the most correct enlightenment, they should then eliminate the thought of permanence, the thought of peace, the thought of suffering, the thought of sentient beings, and the thought of the lifespan of a person. Discerning and understanding without attachment, they should not rely on anything.
By engaging in this practice, one attains the unsurpassed true path.
When the Buddha was practicing the bodhisattva path in the past, he practiced this path and thus attained the Dharma of non-attainment of wisdom, which is called the Buddha's path.
At that time, the Buddha spoke a verse, saying:
Understanding the concept of permanence as illusory, clinging to permanence leads to birth and death.
Permanence and impermanence are empty and nonexistent; seeking the Dharma, there is nothing to be found.
Sentient beings have the concept of peace, but peace is naturally empty.
This concept is inverted, because the concept gives rise to the notion of a person.
If one understands the Dharma, there is no difference between each other,
Then one does not harbor expectations, there is no life, and no person.
The path is not attained by illumination, nor is it so by the absence of the path.
This is called original purity, because the Dharma is nonexistent.
If there is one who is enlightened, understanding that existence is originally pure,
Good son, you should understand that this is the right path.
Not practicing the path, not riding the Buddha's vehicle for rescue,
If someone disputes this, they will not understand the Dharma;
Not practicing the work of wisdom, not being protected by the path,
Because of not following this practice, the Buddha's teachings are profound and difficult to understand.
All dharmas have no dharma, originally all formless,
What exists is also empty and non-existent, the three realms are eternally unstable.
Considering all pleasures as suffering, like walking in empty space,
If one can contemplate this practice, then the mind is liberated.
The body is said to be the self, but that dharma is also empty and non-existent,
Where there is no self, what is known has no existence.
These do not think of life, unable to investigate the root and end,
Empty and formless is true reality, little understanding is confused;
The self and life span are originally pure and nonexistent,
The practice of the ignorant is to reckon the originally pure as existent.
The Buddha's path is inconceivable, not thinking of this as existent,
If one hears the profound and wonderful Dharma, one is unable to accept and uphold it.
Never before has such a sutra been expounded,
The Dharma cannot be attained, and what is said also has no acquisition.
Sitting under the Buddha tree, thus attaining the wisdom of enlightenment,
If one does not attain the wisdom of the Way, then one also has no knowledge.
The Buddha's path and the field of wisdom are also without words or speech,
The foolish give rise to expectant thoughts, longing for the Dharma expounded by the Buddha;
This is the true teaching, the profound and wonderful Dharma proclaimed by the Buddha,
The mind that awakens to the profound, this is the practice of Mara.
If there are any who hear this sutra spoken by the Buddha,
Not understanding the meaning of the sutras, all dharmas are to be protected.
Bodhisattvas undergo great hardship, not seeking the peace of the Way,
In this, there is no realization of the Way, these two things are formless.
The mind should rely on this, this is what the Buddha says,
What is this? How is this? Attached to inverted karma;
If there is suffering and distress, greatly attached to the profound and wonderful,
Each raises a great sound, rejoicing in the inconceivable Buddha.
The Buddha again told SubhÅ«ti:

Those who study this Dharma should cultivate the profound scriptures. Do not set your mind on miscellaneous phrases and many words that lack beneficial meaning, which do not accomplish true and ultimate great wisdom;
The profound and distant Dharma is called profound, this is called the Dharma, this is called the unattainable.
Sentient beings fall into error and cannot practice this, not using samÄdhi to understand the beneficial meaning.
Wisdom has no realm, and the absence of wisdom is also thus. One should understand that this is not the domain of cognition.
The Buddha in the past, upon hearing this profound Dharma, understood it to be tranquil and pure, with no attachment in the mind.

If one hears this sutra and experiences joy, it is because one has cultivated and established meritorious virtues in the presence of innumerable Buddhas in the past, received and embraced it in the mind, recited and upheld it, transformed others, and proclaimed it in the ten directions.
The Buddha further told the youth Sudasaputra:
Bodhisattvas should cultivate such great vows. In the world, people are always filled with fear. One should diligently study the truth and not be afraid.
If one is afraid and retreats, one should understand this and proclaim and uphold it in order to enter the wisdom of the Way.
Sudasaputra then said to the Buddha:
Yes, I joyfully believe in it. What the world does not believe in, I alone firmly believe without end, with aspirations as vast as empty space, forever without any longing.
The Buddha further said to Sudasaputra:

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas aspire to the profound and wondrous Dharma, these true men, through this skillful means in accordance with the Buddha's teachings, will have nothing to dispute in the Dharma of the Way, and because of having nothing to dispute, they will have no fear regarding all dharmas, and all [dharmas] cannot be cut off;
All dharmas are understood to be originally non-existent, and aspiring to nothing, one then enters the wisdom of the Way.
If there are those who hear it said that all dharmas exist, they should not be afraid of it;
If it is said that they do not exist, they should not be alarmed by it.
Regarding existent and non-existent dharmas, one should not increase or decrease what is heard:
Dharmas should be, dharmas should not be, dharmas should be diligent, dharmas should be lazy.
Understanding this is the return of all dharmas in the ten directions to wisdom.
If there is nowhere to return, and if one further does not understand that all dharmas have mindfulness and all dharmas have no mindfulness, one should not be afraid;
All conditioned phenomena and unconditioned phenomena, all phenomena with realms and without realms, all joyful phenomena and joyless phenomena, do not cause fear;

All phenomena are neither conditioned nor unconditioned, all phenomena originally have existence and originally have non-existence, all phenomena are tranquil and all phenomena are agitated, do not cause fear;
All phenomena are inverted and non-inverted, all phenomena are empty and real, and are unconditioned, do not cause fear;

All phenomena have precepts and no precepts, have illumination and no illumination, have names and no names, have arising and no arising, have fear and no fear, have birth and no birth, have death and no death, do not cause fear;
All phenomena have the path and all phenomena have no path, all phenomena have liberation and do not have liberation, all phenomena are so and not so, do not cause fear.
Why is it so?
All dharmas are empty, illusory, unreal, like a mirage, a phantom, a bubble, a plantain, a shadow, an echo, a floating hair before the eyes;
Like what is seen in a dream, originally coming from nowhere, going nowhere upon leaving.

Just like empty space, suddenly appearing with clouds, mist, dust, smoke, ash, etc., appearing in the empty space, unable to defile it, suddenly disappearing, the empty space itself is also not purified.
The worldly wisdom and insight of the path and no path, universally understanding the natural, then being without attachment.
Understanding without understanding, then in accord with the wisdom of the path, the unsurpassed true reality, without fear, the mind not harboring anxiety.
The Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
All dharmas are non-existent, naturally empty and unreal,
That which is naturally empty and non-existent, this characteristic is already nirvÄá¹‡a;
All dharmas are without dispute, this also does not exist,
By understanding all dharmas as non-existent, one penetrates the natural non-existence.
The various disputed dharmas are also non-existent.
By understanding dharmas to be empty and non-existent, one then understands non-disputation.
All dharmas are non-existent, originally pure and eternally formless.
The originally pure cannot be attained, and there is also nothing to forget or lose.
Cutting off all dharmas is called the enlightened wisdom.
This is called eternally destroyed, and also presently nothing is destroyed;
All dharmas are non-extinguished, and also not established by reckoning,
And also mostly nothing is destroyed, and dharmas cannot be attained.
All dharmas are originally empty and non-existent, and also cannot be seen,
If there is nothing to attain, expediently manifesting what exists;
All dharmas are non-existent, arising from conditions and objects,
What exists and what does not exist, expounding the scriptures.
All dharmas are able to correspond, manifesting non-disputation,
Non-disputation is natural, ultimately formless;
All dharmas have nothing to correspond to, no creation, no extinction,
Thus unattainable, always apart from all conceptual proliferation.
All dharmas are unattainable, and there is no past,
How profound and eternally unreal, then called the true limit of reality.
All dharmas are delighted, yet also cannot be delighted,
If dharmas are unattainable, then they also have no verbal expression.
All dharmas are free from negligence, both are non-existent,
Naturally nothing to grasp, this is the profound and wondrous characteristic.
All dharmas are unknowable, selfless and natural,
By understanding the absence of intentionality, one reaches the appellation of naturalness.
Unconditioned, without enjoyment, that also has no existence,
Using existence and non-existence as deluded action, therefore called the unconditioned.
If one contemplates all dharmas, ultimately unobtainable,
This is true speech, therefore called mental contemplation;
Not contemplating any dharmas, no abiding, no returning,
Realizing this has no sentient beings, called the Dharma among Dharmas.
All dharmas are like illusions, the illusions have no existence;
Because dharmas are without illumination, therefore birth and death are proclaimed.
All dharmas are without form or appearance, this is the meaning of naturalness;
If there are no dharmas, liberation has no liberation.
Provisionally called the realm, naturally without a realm,
The ignorant rely and attach to it, therefore called the realm.
The Buddha further told SubhÅ«ti:ğŸ”½Form, sensation, perception, impulse, and consciousness are empty, originally non-existent;
Eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind are empty, originally non-existent;
Earth, water, fire, wind, and space are originally also formless;
They are formed through causes and conditions, just like the five things that make up a house.
What are the five?
First, timber; second, tiles and thatch; third, earth and moats; fourth, human effort; fifth, mud and water - by these five things a house is made.
Originally, when they are separate, they are not called a house at all.
The body is also like this, formed through causes and conditions.
The five skandhas and four elements come together, and for that reason it is called a body.

Earth, water, fire, and wind each come together through causes and conditions, just like the four pillars and four walls of a house, all coming together through causes and conditions, formed and then scattered, with no fixed location.

It is like seeing a house, city walls, trees, flowers and fruits, flowing water, fields and land, oxen plowing, and planting the five grains in a dream, each growing in its season, the owner of the house using it to provide for himself.

The ignorance of the mind-spirit does not understand that the entire three realms are empty. Relying on hope, it gives rise to the thinking consciousness, and the twelve links of dependent arising come and go in circles, revolving without end, exhausting the spirit and consciousness, sinking and wandering in the five destinies without a moment of rest.
Not understanding the original emptiness, it is like seeing in a dream, waking up not knowing where it went.
Only when one attains perfect enlightenment does one understand that the five destinies originally have no location, and one can walk alone without fear.
The Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
Form, sensation, perception, and consciousness are empty, as are the eyes, ears, nose, mouth, and mind.
Originally tranquil, they do not exist. Earth, water, wind, and fire are different.
Understanding the realms, one attains mastery, and proclaims the chapters of the non-sectarian teachings.
What is said to be the Buddha lands above are realms of thoughts of nirvana.
All dharmas each have form, but originally they are also not combined.
Not understanding emptiness and tranquility, their original nature is without a body;
There is nothing that cannot be attained, arising from conditions and combining to form,
There is nothing that cannot be reached, and yet one hopes to attain birth.
Not cultivating precepts there, and also not violating prohibitions,
No practice, no precepts, this is the characteristic of all dharmas.
All dharmas are non-existent, arising from ignorance,
Using the dharma of ignorance, one creates penetrating wisdom.
All dharmas have provisional names, this is called non-existence,
Provisional names have no dharma, this is called nirvana.
What arises has no birth, due to the present five aggregates,
The aggregates are unseen, due to the present there is what is manifested.
What exists has no location, due to transformation a dharma is shown to exist,
The dharma is apart from the karma of birth and death, for a long time free from the difficulty of birth and death.
Like a magician creating a form, the ignorant consider it a person,
The wise are not confused by existence and non-existence.
The Dharma arises without arising; the wise do not conceive of it.
All dharmas are empty; the foolish do not understand this.
As soon as the Dharma arises, it will perish.
Birth, sickness, and death - abandoning these, there is no fear.
All dharmas are empty; the Dharma also has no return.
Good thoughts should understand this; this is the Dharma expounded by the Buddha.
The Right Enlightenment is without action; it cannot be attained.
If one does not attain the Way, then one sees the affairs of the three realms.
If one hopes for the Buddha's Way, then one does not seek the Right Enlightenment.
If one practices with the aspiration for the Way, one will never create the formless.
All birth and death is natural; do not contemplate the natural Dharma.
Nature is without existence; this is the conception of the unconditioned.
Ultimately unborn, what is spoken of cannot be attained,
By practicing the karma of ignorance, the unconditioned Dharma is shown.
Embracing the many meanings, the various principles are naturally so,
They are all unborn, and then there are no disputes;
They have nothing that is not practiced, the profound and wonderful Dharma that is proclaimed,
Using all that arises, the bodhisattvas practice compassion.
At that time, SubhÅ«ti replied to the World-Honored One in verse, saying:
The Buddha appears in the world, all out of pity for us,
The body is taken as a net of doubts, proclaiming this Dharma meaning.
The Buddha's appearance is inconceivable, fully endowed with transformations,
Destroying the net of MÄra, speaking of eliminating the sixty-two;
Cutting off the root of birth and death, therefore sitting under the Buddha tree,
Forever without hesitation, proclaiming to eliminate the attachments of the multitude;
You have explained the emptiness of false karma, and the Able One has extinguished all views,
Heroic for the sake of the world, you have severed my many doubts.
At that time the World-Honored One said to the youth Sudasaputra:

The practices of the bodhisattva are never false. He saves and protects many, bestows kindness and aid, and is free from disputes. He removes all faults and is completely pure. He pities sentient beings and practices profound and distant principles, without harboring expectations. The world is not solid, so he eliminates greed and desire. Without greed and desire, he discards the many bonds. He always practices equanimity and extends it to sentient beings. His resolve is not false.
